results.title: Malaysia: land of contrasts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
A two part tour of Malaysia. Part 1: Kuala Lumpur, Cameron Highlands, Kuantan & Terengganu. A survey of the temples, shopping centres and gardens of the Malaysian capital, Kuala Lumpur; the jungle walks and hill stations of the Cameron Highlands, and the beautiful beaches of Pahang, Kuantan and Terengganu. Part 2: Penang, Ipoh, Genting Highlands, Negeri Sembilan & Melaka. The tour continues through the cities of Penang, Ipoh and Melaka and the palaces and castles of Negeri Sembilan and the Genting Highlands.

results.title: Bangkok - the City of Angels/the Kingdom of Thailand
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Colin Baker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Bangkok: The City of Angels - Bangkok, capital of the Kingdom of Thailand is one of Asia’s most popular destinations. Enjoy the breathtaking Royal Palace, the ornate Royal Barges and Bangkok’s beautiful temples, the magic of the Viman Mek Teak Palace - “The Castle in the Clouds”, the world’s largest golden teak structure, the bustle of the Floating Markets, the ancient capital of Atyutthaya, the beautiful River Kwai (with its famous bridge), visit the Rose Garden and enjoy its exuberant and lavish stage presentation, complete with elephant show. Bangkok is famous for its food and shopping, contrast the tempo and excitement of modern day Bangkok, with the tranquil splendour of the Ancient City. “The Kingdom of Thailand” - Siam, as it was once known, with its delightful people, offers the traveller unlimited attractions - the fun and sun of Pattaya, the beauty of Chiang Mai, “Thailand’s Northern Shangri-la” with visits to the Hill Tribes and elephant camps, visit Chiang Rai and the famed Golden Triangle and join the wedding celebrations of a remote Hill tribe. Rated: G

results.title: Japan - Land of the Rising Sun
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Part 1: Tokyo and Yokohama - In Tokyo, one of the largest cities in the world, Japan’s traditional past mixes with the streamlined present. The bustling sophistication of the Ginza, with its renowned department stores and shopping, contrast with the historic Imperial Palace. Yokohama has a famous harbour and colourful history. Yokohama’s many attractions include its historic Chinatown, the Marine Tower, the beautiful Sankeien Gardens, and the amazing City of Tomorrow. Part 2: Kyoto, Hakone, Okayame and Kanazawa. Japan’s former capital, the ancient city of Kyoto with its palaces, wonderful temples and delightful parks is full of charm. Famed Gion Corner with its introduction to Japanese arts and theatre and the talent of the Geisha. Visit the Heian Shrine to see a Japanese wedding and contemplate the stunning Golden Pavilion of the Kinkakuji Temple. History and beauty combine to greet twenty million visitors to Hakone’s many attractions include the celebrated Open Air Museum. Okayama, Kurashiki and Kanazawa have many attractions to offer including castles, museums, beautiful gardens and markets and arts and crafts. Rated: G

results.title: India: Delhi and Agra, Rajasthan and Kashmir
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Delhi, capital of India, and steeped in history, is the perfect start to any trip to India, the land of fascinating contrasts. Visit the bustling bazaars, the Red Fort, former citadel of the Moghul emperors…and New Delhi with its stately structures and underground markets, dungeons and sprawling ruins. Agra home of the Taj Mahal. Stroll down Agra’s exotic streets and marvel at its attractions…the forts, palaces and tombs of past emperors. Rajasthan and Kashmir - enchanting palaces, impregnable forts, uncompromising deserts and tranquil lakes. Kashmir - overlooked by the mighty Himalayas. Its wonderful mountain streams, forests and beautiful lakes with their famous houseboats. Moghul gardens and romantic architecture, make Kashmir the Jewel in the Crown of India.

results.title: Hong Kong the Fragrant Harbour & Macau City
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Colin Baker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Hong Kong, one of the most exciting destinations in the Orient. Contrast the historic past with the vibrant present. Explore old Hong Kong with its shops, stalls and diverse merchandise, ancient temples, the bird restaurant, the Jade market. See the wonderful harbour, surveyed by Victoria Peak and the outlying islands. The floating village of sampan dwellers - Aberdeen with its famed floating restaurants, and the delightful Ocean Park with its many attractions. Macau, the extraordinary and colourful Portuguese colony, a mere dot on the map of China, and one of the first gateways to the, then unknown, Celestial Kingdom of China. This fascinating colony where East and West blend so easily, has an incredible history. Apart from its rich history, Macau offers visitors the opportunity to try their luck with 24 hour casinos, a wide variety of restaurants, excellent shopping and a charming and friendly people. Rated: G

results.title: That mouse
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A white mouse cavorts about the forest, mostly on the back of a bumbling black bear, creating such a stir that other forest creatures (a deer, a tortoise, a hawk and a hound) have to put a stop to it. Children will enjoy the way the animals speak with human voices and act out their parts.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Rubbo, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: That's the price
results.creator_credit: Michael Scott, William Canning and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Two points of view concerning what the infusion of industrial capital meant to two dying coal towns in southeastern British Columbia. The film shows what happened when an American corporation came to the twin towns of Natal and Michel with a contract for millions of tons of coking coal for the steel mills of Japan. From what is seen and said in this film, industrial growth has its price, especially with regard to the ecology of the region.

results.title: That's surfing
results.brief_description: This comprehensive documentary looks at Australia’s long running love affair with the ocean and in particular, with surfing. The evolution of the modern surfboard is traced, as well as the emergence of surfing films, music, magazines and surfwear fashion industries. We see the surfboard manufacturing industries that have emerged in coastal towns such as Torquay where surfer-craftsmen experiment in their eternal quest for the perfect board. The development of the Australian surfing subculture is shown, from the influential U.S. surfers who arrived at the 1956 Olympic Games with their Malibu boards, to the female surfers in the 60’s who were largely disregarded unless they were tandem surfing with male partners. This culture is not only embraced by groups of mates who tour beaches in their panel vans but increasingly by the professional surfers who move around the world touring circuits from the Seychelles to Bali, and take out world titles in Hawaii. Historic clashes surfers have had with authorities are presented, as well as music clips of Australian surfing songs from Little Pattie, Col Joye, The Delltones, Normie Rowe and Johnny O’Keefe. The program is a blend of historical surfing footage, interview clips and cameo appearances from most of Australia’s surfing greats from the 1950’s through to the 1990’s including Midge Farrelly, Nat Young, Layne Beachley, Kelly Slater and Mark Occhilupo.

The development of the Australian surfing subculture is shown, from the influential U.S. surfers who arrived at the 1956 Olympic Games with their Malibu boards, to the female surfers in the 60’s who were largely disregarded unless they were tandem surfing with male partners. This culture is not only embraced by groups of mates who tour beaches in their panel vans but increasingly by the professional surfers who move around the world touring circuits from the Seychelles to Bali, and take out world titles in Hawaii. Historic clashes surfers have had with authorities are presented, as well as music clips of Australian surfing songs from Little Pattie, Col Joye, The Delltones, Normie Rowe and Johnny O’Keefe. The program is a blend of historical surfing footage, interview clips and cameo appearances from most of Australia’s surfing greats from the 1950’s through to the 1990’s including Midge Farrelly, Nat Young, Layne Beachley, Kelly Slater and Mark Occhilupo.
description_for_label: This comprehensive documentary looks at Australia’s long running love affair with the ocean and in particular, with surfing. The evolution of the modern surfboard is traced, as well as the emergence of surfing films, music, magazines and surfwear fashion industries. We see the surfboard manufacturing industries that have emerged in coastal towns such as Torquay where surfer-craftsmen experiment in their eternal quest for the perfect board. The development of the Australian surfing subculture is shown, from the influential U.S. surfers who arrived at the 1956 Olympic Games with their Malibu boards, to the female surfers in the 60’s who were largely disregarded unless they were tandem surfing with male partners. This culture is not only embraced by groups of mates who tour beaches in their panel vans but increasingly by the professional surfers who move around the world touring circuits from the Seychelles to Bali, and take out world titles in Hawaii. Historic clashes surfers have had with authorities are presented, as well as music clips of Australian surfing songs from Little Pattie, Col Joye, The Delltones, Normie Rowe and Johnny O’Keefe. The program is a blend of historical surfing footage, interview clips and cameo appearances from most of Australia’s surfing greats from the 1950’s through to the 1990’s including Midge Farrelly, Nat Young, Layne Beachley, Kelly Slater and Mark Occhilupo.

results.title: Malaysia: sparrow with sparrow, raven with raven
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, John Temple and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Asian insight”.
A look at the historical and cultural background of Malaysia. Religion and politics play an important part in the life style of the people. Suitable for secondary level.
